div.head: M. DE HUMBOLDT.

p.hi: TO THE EDITOR OF THE COURIER.

div.p: Paris, Grand Hôtel de Richelieu, May 12, 1825.

Sir—Having travelled in New Spain, and knowing, from
what I have seen and experienced, the inestimable value and
correctness of M. de Humboldt’s works, I felt not a liitle sur-
prised to hear that distinguished traveller constantly aecnsod of
exaggeration and inaccuracy. If those, who thus endenvour to
detract from the merits of M. de Humboldt’s work, are not so
alive to the beauties of nature as he is, we must recollect, that there
is, perhaps, no man now existing, who combines with the
depth and details of almost every science, so much general know-
ledge; and to such a mind, that may have the greatest value,
which by ordinary and superficial observers would be slightly
noticed, because they are unble to @ it. As, however,
I had heard M. de Humboldt accu ed of uttering @ doli@erate
falsehood, which no warmth of feeling or liveliness of imagina-
tion could justify; as I have in vain endeavoured to combat the
interpretation often put upon the passage alluded to; and as an
attack has been made upon him in a work recently published —
(Bullock’s Mexico, vide note at the eud of chap. vii.) — on coming
to Paris, and having had the honour and pleasure of making M.
de Humboldt’s acquaintance, I ventured to mention the subject
to him, and then he very kindly addressed to me the enclosed.

J’ai dit dans l’edition originale Française Essai Politique, en 4to.
T. 1. p. 80. Introd. p. 17.

“Pour @eux distinguer les volcans actives des volcans eteints
je me suis permis d’ajouter une petite colonne de fumée aux
dessins du Pic d’Orizaba et du Grand Volcan de la Puebla, quoi-
que je n’aie observée cette fumêe ni à Zalapa, ni à Mexico.
Nous avons vu sortir une grande masse des cendres et des vapeurs
très denses de la bouche du Popocatepetl le 24 Juin 1804, dans
la plaine de Tetimba, près de San Nicolas de los Ranchos:”

“Le Popocatepetl forme un cone enorme dont la cratére, con-
stamment enflamme, jettant de la fumée et des cendres s’ouvre
au milieu des neiges eternelles!”

Ce passage n’indique certainement pas que l’on voit de la ſumée
de Mexico méme; il dit, que le cratére jette encore tous les ans@
j’aurois pu dire tous les mois, de la ſumée: elle se voit dans la
plaine de Tetimba, an pic du volcan. Le tremblement de
terre du 13 Janvier 1804, ſut accompagné d’une forte ejection de
cendres et de ſumée. Les ejections sont trés communes au mois
de Mai et entre 4 et 6 heures du soir. La direction de la ſumée
sert même aux Indiens de voisinage de pronostic meteoroligique.

M. de Humboldt serait très reconnoissant à Monsicur Stapleton,
s’il vouloit bien repandre ces éclaircissemens; car il tient beau-
coup plus à la reputation d’un voyageur verédique qu’a celle de
l’esprit et du savoir.

By this it will appear, that in that faithful and beautiful de-
scription (T. 1. p. 179, chap. viii.) of the view to be seen on a
fine morm@g from the tower of the cathedral of Mexico, or from
the hill. of Chapultepetl, M. de H. does nor mean to say that he
has seen from either of those points the smoke issuing from the
erater of Popocatepetl, but only that it is constantly inflamed,
that smoke does issue from it, and that he himself, when near to
the erater, was present with M. Boupland at an eruption of smoke
and as hes. The greatest wonders of our globe being to the in-
habita @ts of New Spain an every day scene, they are less alive to
them than the stranger, who is surprised, on inquiring after the
curiosi ties in their immediate vicinity (to see which he has cross-
ed the. Atlantic), to find them often ignorant even of their exist-
ence. I had in vain made various and anxious inquiries at Mex-
ico resp@ecting the activity of the volcano of Popocatepetl—all
agreed that there had been no eruption within the last century.
At last, one morning, when I was riding before breakſast from
Mexico to the Penol de los Banos, I met an Indian, who, in re-
ply to my questions, told me, that during the dry season, when
the wind blew from the north, he had occasionally seen the smoke
even from the city of Mexico! In Europe, we must be surprised
to hear, that such a fact should be only known to an Indian; but
that surprise will cease, when we consider the indolence and
indifference of the enlightened classes in that country, and the
immense distance from Mexico of the summit of a mountain,
which rises into the Heavens near 18,000 feet above the level of
the sea, covered with eternal snows, and for ever inaccessible to
man.

Cortez in his letters, A. D. 1519, alludes to the smoke of Popo-
catepetl.

A grand eruption which took place in 1540 is mentioned by
Gormora.—(Hist. Mex. pub. 1553.)

The last great eruption, according to Torquemada, was in
15@4.

I subjoin some extracts from M. de H’s Journal, which have
not yet been published, and which he has very obligingly com-
municated to me:—

“The rock of Popocatepetl is obsidian porphyry. The crater
itself is easily to be seen with a glass, but as it iuclines towards
the East as all the great volcanic cones in these parts do), it is
not visible from the city of Mexico. The smell of sulphureous
vapours can be perceived below the limits of the snow. These
vapours are considered by the Indians as a presage of weather.
When in the evening, a black smoke arises from the crater, and
forms itself into a cloud, inclining to the north, it is thouglrt to
portend rain; when it inclines to the south, it is looked upon as
the forerunner of a severe frost; when it arises perpendicularly,
it is said to announce a storm. At times, two or three hours be-
fore the storm is felt in the inferior regions, clouds of pumice
stone and ashes arise from the crater, and they may be seen roll-
ing down wards upon the snow, as particles of sand. There was
a violent storm accompanying the earthquake on the 13th of Ja-
nuary, 1804, and a considerable eruption of smoke and ashes from
the mouth of the crater. The smoke is seldom to be seen in the
morning; generally from four to s x in the evening, particularly
at the setting of the sun, and more frequently in the month of
May. The Indians assured me, that at that period, the whole
tops sometimes assumed a red-yellowish colour, which may be
attributed to the sulphureous vapours. At night, however, no
fire has ever been seen within the memory of man.”

Those who have visited the volcanoes of the New World, and
of the West Indian Islands, know, that this constant state of in-
flammation and emission of smoke is common to almost all of
them. I descended last year, into the crater of that of Guada-
loupe (tlie elevation of which is near 6000 feet above the level of
the sea), and had my hands scorched in procuring some of the
burning sulphur, which glimmers of a bright yellow, through
the clouds of smoke in different parts of the interior of the crater.
In the Island of Dominica, I have seen several burning craters
of the some description. Such also was precisely the state of the
volcano of St. Vincent’s before the remarkable eruption of 1812,
which covered ships with ashes at two or three hundred Eng-
lish miles to the windward, This has been endeavoured to be explained by the counter-currents
of air prevalent in the Tropics; and blowing in a direction contrary to
that of the trade-winds. as well as the island of Barbadoes,
at eighty miles distance, and the noise of which was heard at
Antigua, (and I believe at St. Thomas’s,) where it was thought
to be an engagement between the two fleets of France and Great
Brrtain, though (wonderful to relate) not heard by the inhabi-
tants of the smaller islands in the immediate vicinily of St. Vin-
cent’s itself. These burning mountains acquire the greatest in-
terest from the consideration, that though now apparently in an
almost passive state, they may, by convulsion, become, when
least expected, vast engines of the most horrible destruction. The
giving way of a layer of earth, undermined by slow fire, may
cause an eruption and shake the universe.
